timeline.bodyText: I think we should add such an annotation to the API package or some util package. It is useful documentation and a bit nicer than a comment.
timeline.author: Oberon00

replies.bodyText: The annotation has been around for a looong time and I've never seen any tooling use it. Is it much better than a comment? Then we wouldn't need to maintain the annotation.
replies.author: anuraaga

replies.bodyText: Hmm, no strong opinion. If you think the annotation fits badly, comments should be fine too.
replies.author: Oberon00

timeline.author: Oberon00

replies.bodyText: Oops for some reason thought this was in-memory
replies.author: anuraaga

replies.bodyText: Wouldn't the overhead be even worse then, relatively speaking? EDIT: Depending on whether the I/O does some internal buffering.
replies.author: Oberon00

timeline.bodyText: With the getOrDefault, can't you keep it as a single expression? Also, I think we have some isNullOrEmpty helper already in the propagator-utils.
timeline.author: Oberon00

replies.bodyText: Yeah don't think we can use propagator classes here. We could move it to API to the internal package, but so far we don't leak internal classes across artifacts in this repo. I think it's ok though so if others thing so too I could do that.
replies.author: anuraaga

timeline.bodyText: Shouldn't one abort also if read == 0? AFAIK this is documented to only happen at EOF.
timeline.author: Oberon00

timeline.bodyText: Even in Java 7, there is a stdlib API that does that: https://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/nio/file/Files.html#readAllBytes(java.nio.file.Path)
timeline.author: Oberon00

replies.bodyText: Not on Android - but I realized, this module should not have the Android sniffer on... Nice!
replies.author: anuraaga

timeline.bodyText: Shouldn't we shortcut and return empty here if size == 0? Or if we want to support files that report their size wrongly, we would need a different approach from the pre-allocated array.
timeline.author: Oberon00

timeline.bodyText: Since zPages are an optional, experimental extension which you probably wouldn't use if resources are tight, I wouldn't mind keeping the Guava dependency for it.
timeline.author: Oberon00

replies.bodyText: Yeah this is the one line that gets most benefit from Guava. I'm mixed, 2MB dependency just for this function, mostly :)
replies.author: anuraaga

timeline.bodyText: Are you sure trimming is OK here? In an URL we shouldn't have any spaces encoded as such anyway.
timeline.author: Oberon00

replies.bodyText: Also, you trim again below, so this is definitely redundant.
replies.author: Oberon00

replies.bodyText: Hmm - not sure just reproing the current code for now
replies.author: anuraaga

timeline.author: Oberon00

timeline.bodyText:
Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
                                  .filter(s -> !s.isEmpty())
          
          
            
                                  .map(String::trim)
          
      
    
    
  

Should not be needed. Also spaces may be relevant here.
timeline.author: Oberon00

timeline.bodyText: Why only decode selectively here? Shouldn't all keys and values be decoded?
timeline.author: Oberon00

replies.bodyText: Think I agree - would probably fix that separately from guava refactoring.
replies.author: anuraaga

timeline.bodyText: I think a normal foreach loop would be more readable.
timeline.author: Oberon00

replies.bodyText: Hmm - I've always appreciated Java 8's Map.forEach since Entry can be a bit gross :)
replies.author: anuraaga

replies.bodyText:
Alternatively, how about some casting? https://stackoverflow.com/a/17209434/2128694
Map<String, String> map = (Map<String, String>)(Map)properties;
replies.author: Oberon00

timeline.bodyText: I think you might need to swap the order of trim/isEmpty to match Guava. AFAIK omitEmptyStrings only sets a boolean. But I may be wrong here.
timeline.author: Oberon00

replies.bodyText: Whether or not it matches guava, this logic seems right. Values that are only whitespace shouldn't be used, I don't think.
replies.author: jkwatson

replies.bodyText: My not splitting the PRs up in advance caused this review to be a bit hectic, sorry about that. While GitHub doesn't have the outdated mark here, if I remember correctly, the code used to be in the wrong order and @Oberon00 commented and I fixed it so it should be good now.
replies.author: anuraaga

timeline.bodyText: Didn't we have some Utils.checkArgument function?
timeline.author: Oberon00

replies.bodyText: Yeah we have it in API - if we're ok with cross-referencing from other artifacts (guess it's ok) I'll use it
replies.author: anuraaga

replies.bodyText: Yeah, the SDK uses API classes quite a bit (obviously because it has to implement it!). I think this is a fine usage, as long as it's not in a strictly "internal" package.
replies.author: jkwatson

timeline.bodyText: You can't write the full buffer here. You need to check how many bytes you actually read into the buffer, which may be less.
timeline.author: Oberon00
